speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the optimism bias is a cognitive bias where our expectations are better than reality and what's interesting about the optimism bias is that you might think in order to make the best decisions in life and have the best life outcomes you should represent information as it is in reality and not have expectations that are better than reality but the optimism bias shows us that if we
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: think things are better than they are and overestimate the likelihood of good things happening, we have all these better life outcomes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So people who are optimistic have a lower risk of all-cause mortality and reduced risk of cardiovascular disease.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They have decreased fatigue and chronic illness, and they engage in more self-care behaviors.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: There's even this really cool study that showed that people who are optimistic had improved cognitive functioning following a traumatic brain injury.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Optimists, they just earn more money, they have better immune systems, and they just have less anxiety and worry overall.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So why would it be that being optimistic and thinking things are better than they are leads to all these positive things?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So to explain that, I'm going to go through an example.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So imagine here you're someone who holds the reality beliefs.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So in reality, it's true that 50% of marriages end in divorce.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If you work out, you reduce your risk of heart disease by 14%.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And if you eat well, you reduce your risk of cancer by 10%.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But then imagine that you're someone who's optimistic.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if you're optimistic, you might think, no, only 10% of marriages end in divorce.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If I work out, I'll reduce my risk of heart disease by 40%.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And if I eat well, I'll reduce my risk of cancer by 30%.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if we hold these optimistic beliefs, we're going to be way more likely to do these things.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we'll be more likely to eat well.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We're going to be more likely to work out and we're going to be more likely to go out there with the hope of finding a partner.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And although not everything will work out for you because the reality statistics are there on the left, by going out and engaging in more activities and things in life, we increase our chances of some things working out.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's like the idea of minimizing the risk of missed opportunity.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If I do go out there and work out and go to parties and eat well and all these things, I'm going to have more likely chance of some of them working out than if I just stay at home and don't do anything.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So being optimistic increases our engagement in the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this overall is a positive thing that can lead to all these health benefits.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if optimism is really good for all these things, what is the connection between optimism and mental health?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So people with anxiety and depression have been shown to lack optimism.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They can either have expectations that are worse than reality.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this can be pessimism.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Or they can have expectations that match reality.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is sometimes called depressive realism, which as we've kind of gone over that this isn't a good thing either.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what I'm interested in is, well, could we increase optimism as an intervention for depression and anxiety?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's what, what I, what I, what I want to do.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And it suggests that the optimism bias is something that we're born with.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's something, it's not like other biases that, that we learn later on.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's something that is, is a part of us.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's the idea of the first experiment.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this can be things that happened to you in childhood, if you're exposed to trauma, your socioeconomic status, these kinds of things.

text: So people who usually have gone through more adversity during childhood have lower optimism.

text: And another thing is that people who are optimistic have improved cardiovascular responses to stress.

text: So this means that they have a healthier arousal outcome.

text: So if you're anxious, you can have just high arousal overall.

text: So for experiment two, we use the belief updating task that's used in literature.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is a standard optimism task that's used in humans.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the way this task works is a participant is asked to estimate the likelihood of a bad thing happening.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what's the likelihood you'll develop cancer?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And you give that estimation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then the participant is shown the actual likelihood of that estimation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that likelihood can be lower or higher than their estimation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if they're told their risk of something bad is lower, that's considered a good news trial because they've just been given good news.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Whereas if they're told their risk of something is worse, that's a bad news trial because they've just been given bad news.

text: And you can look at how much

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we set up the task so we had the optimism and pessimism state factor.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if the agent was in an optimistic state, it updated more to a good outcome than a bad outcome.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If the agent was in a pessimistic state, it updated more to a bad outcome than a good outcome.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: the likelihood matrix here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: There was an initial hidden state factor, which was the belief about the good versus bad outcome.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the agent gets this belief about the good versus bad outcome.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They're then fed observations, which is either better than expected or worse, so good news or bad news.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So they're given good news or bad news observations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then, so then they are updating their hidden state factor belief from the observation of good versus bad news.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And whether they're in an optimistic or pessimistic state, this influences how much they update to good versus bad news.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the optimism state factor is conditioned on this updating here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then we took the difference between the initial hidden state factor belief, so that's here, compared to the hidden state factor belief after the observation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's the D and then in the next step.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And in this two-armed bandit task, what we did was the agent could either select left or right.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So left was high risk, high reward, right was low risk, low reward.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Or there was a third option where the agent could select stay.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this was like the safe option.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if you selected stay, you didn't lose any money, but you didn't win any money.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this is an important thing to be able to model for what we're interested in, because if you are depressed and you're not optimistic,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: one of the things that you can tend to do is, is stay at home and not go out and engage in all those things that, that I was talking about at the start of the talk.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's, it's helpful if we can see, um, to model this, what, what, who would be decided making this decision to stay, stay, you know, just stay safe, stay at home, not, but not getting any rewards overall.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And one of the, uh,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: this is kind of related to optimism, but one of the, um, interventions for depression at the moment is behavioral activation in cognitive behavioral therapy, which is the idea to get people to go out in, in the world more and engage in more things.

text: So it, it would be good if we could have a task that we can measure this, this decision making.

text: So that's what we, that's what we did.

text: We had this second, our second model had no policies.

text: And then this is where the agent, this is where our optimistic action comes in.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And here again, we have our optimism versus pessimism state factor.

text: So this is what's been going on throughout.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so here we have the generative process, which is actually just the structure of the two-armed bandit task.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if I select left, we've got 70% chance of a large win, 30% chance of a large loss.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If I select right, we've got 65% chance of a small win, 40% chance of a small loss.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is what's going on.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: in the actual task.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this is the belief of the agent.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if you're optimistic, you have this high precision over the large win, and the small wins are just wins in general.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And if you're pessimistic, you have this large precision over the over the loss of the losses rather than the wins.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this is controlled by this state factor here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is how that the agents updating their beliefs.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Um, and we ran, I think it was 60 trials for, for this, for this task.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So here are our results for this task, the total winnings.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so again, we've got our optimism level.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this would be an agent with optimism level 0.9, optimism level 0.1.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is a pessimistic agent.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we can see that the more optimistic an agent is, the more winnings they have overall.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So in this task setting, having this precision over these positive outcomes was led to this higher winnings.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The agent who had the precision over the low outcomes actually ended up losing money.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But what's also important about this figure is that we can see that
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It wasn't that the most optimistic agent had the most winnings.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We see that the agent here has the most winnings.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And an important idea when we're thinking about optimism and interventions is it probably isn't going to be the case that 100% optimism all the time in every situation is a good thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Different environments that we're in, there's going to be different levels of optimism that
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: that are going to be most beneficial.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that's another thing that's what's so nice about being able to do these models is that we can kind of explore what those different levels look like and test that out in different environments rather than just saying, oh, optimism is good.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Let's make everyone optimistic without actually really understanding how it's going on in this sense.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So findings like this are important.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So then we wanted to look at, well, what's the actions of these agents that led them to these different outcomes?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we have our pessimistic agent here, and we can see that they just selected left and right, and then they're just like, no, that's it, I'm just gonna stay.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we can think of this as somebody who might be depressed, who goes out, has some bad times, and they're like, no, I'm just gonna stay at home now.

text: That's not gonna give me any,

text: any of rewards or anything that I'm looking for.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We have this middle agent who kind of went back and forth between the left and right arm.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then here we have the optimistic agent who went right, left, and then just stayed in the left arm, which is the high risk, high reward.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But overall, that would lead you to the most money in the end.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Uh, so this, this is nice because we can see, um, what kind of actions, uh, the actions of how, uh, what kind of actions would result from the different beliefs that these agents have.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this is the behavior that we've been talking about.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So our two armed bandit task, uh, was able to capture optimistic action.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we could see that the optimism promoted the engagement action because the optimistic agents didn't select stay, they kept going in the task, selecting left and right.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We also found that full optimism is not the most beneficial in this task setting, which is an important consideration, especially if we're thinking about interventions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then, yep, so they were the three simulations that we ran.

text: So with these three different simulations, we feel like this is pretty good initial support for an active inference model of optimism.

text: There's a lot of positives about modeling optimism with this active inference model.

text: We can use it in these different task settings.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We've set up models that we can now collect data for.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's the first conclusion.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Our model demonstrated how optimism could be lost in development, which is an important consideration.

text: So we're able to show, okay, this is how it fits to things that are already out there measuring optimism.

text: And our two-armed bandit task was able to show how optimistic action
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: was able to measure the optimistic action.
